title: Emmanuel Macron, a certain idea of power
summary: 'The Two Emmanuel Macrons' (Part 1/4). The French president's decision in June to dissolve the Assemblée Nationale provoked a major political crisis in France. Le Monde looks back in a series of articles at the leader's puzzling evolution.

title: Understanding Nicolas Sarkozy's final conviction in corruption case
summary: On Wednesday, France's highest court of appeals upheld the former French president's sentence for corruption and influence peddling.

title: Trump opposes deal to avert government shutdown
summary: The President-elect has rejected a bipartisan plan to prevent a Christmastime government shutdown, instead telling House Speaker Mike Johnson and Republicans to essentially renegotiate two days before a deadline when federal funding runs out.

title: 'Syria's Ahmad al-Sharaa could be pushed toward a pragmatic, even technocratic form of Islamism'
summary: The victory of the leader of HTS, the al-Qaida-based armed group that toppled Bashar al-Assad, could accelerate his shift from jihadism to conservative Islamism within a national framework, writes Gilles Paris, editorial writer at Le Monde in his column.

title: Trump seeks a way out of the wars in Ukraine and the Middle East
summary: The president-elect's potential future decisions regarding foreign policy remain unclear, due to the lack of coherence in his choices for the Trump administration.

title: Four DIY gifts to make this Christmas
summary: From a denim lampshade to a vintage fabric pouch, a silk scrunchie to the classic Christmas wreath, these four designs are perfect for adding a personal touch to your gifts. They're easy to make at home with just a few (or almost no) materials.

title: Which countries have appeared most on Le Monde's front page, and when?
summary: The newspaper's 24,856 front pages since 1944 to 2024 retrace the last eight decades of major upheavals around the world.

title: Turkish FM rejects Trump claim of Ankara 'takeover' in Syria
summary: Since the early days of the anti-Assad revolt that erupted in 2011, Turkey has been seen as a key backer of the opposition to his rule.

title: James Jeffrey, former US special envoy for Syria: 'Obviously, the US should talk to al-Jolani'
summary: The former member of Donald Trump's first-term administration analyzes Washington's options in the Middle East situation.

title: Devastated Mayotte faces food and water shortages: 'In four days, there will be nothing left to eat'
summary: Getting food to the French territory in the Indian Ocean takes time due to communication difficulties. A curfew has been introduced to prevent the risk of looting.

title: French PM Bayrou already under fire from critics
summary: The new prime minister has been criticized for his response to the cyclone that hit the overseas territory of Mayotte and for his insistence on keeping his office as mayor of Pau.

title: Russia detains suspect in killing of general responsible for use of chemical weapons
summary: Lieutenant General Igor Kirillov, 54, was killed entering his apartment block on Tuesday when a bomb was detonated inside a parked scooter. The suspect said he'd been 'recruited by Ukranian special forces,' according to investigators.

title: For a battered Syrian town, a decade of horrors hard to forget
summary: Muadamiyat al-Sham, on the outskirts of Damascus, saw the worst of Bashar al-Assad's  rule: arbitrary detention, torture, famine, bombings, and chemical weapons. Today, former prisoners, exiles and residents who survived the regime are returning and demanding justice.

title: Justice electrifies Accor Arena in Paris with dazzling show
summary: On Tuesday, the French electro duo performed the first of their two sold-out concerts at the Parisian venue.

title: NASA astronauts, already stuck in the ISS for six months, have to stay until at least end of March
summary: Suni Williams and Butch Wilmore, who initially left for space on an eight-day mission, have been stuck in the International Space Station since June, due to faults on the Boeing Starliner spacecraft that carried them there.

title: Germany's Olaf Scholz tarnishes legacy with coalition infighting
summary: The German chancellor lost a vote of no confidence in the Bundestag on Monday, meaning the country will hold early elections on February 23, 2025. Scholz's record, fairly positive, has been tarnished by the disputes that broke up his coalition.

title: On the Turkish border, Syrian refugees take their first steps back to their homeland
summary: Exiled for years in Turkey, every day several hundred Syrians wait with mingled excitement and apprehension to return home at the crossing points between the two countries.

title: Rekindled love: 'You're not too old to start a love story at 66, it makes you feel younger than ever'
summary: They met, fell in love and separated. And then the whirl of life brought them back together. Didier, 67, shares his story with Sylvia, 62.

title: Zelensky huddles with European leaders as Trump's return looms
summary: The meeting with Nato Chief Mark Rutte and other key European leaders comes a month before Trump reclaims the US presidency, having pledged to bring a swift end to a conflict that NATO says has left more than one million dead and wounded since Russia's 2022 invasion. Once in office, there are fears that Trump could pull US support for Kyiv

title: France declares 'exceptional natural disaster measures' in cyclone-hit Mayotte
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron will be in Mayotte on Thursday, his office said, as officials warned the death toll from the most destructive cyclone in living memory could reach hundreds – possibly thousands.

title: Paul Schrader's 'Oh, Canada': A man's reckoning at the end of his life
summary: The American filmmaker confronts the reality and legend of an ailing documentary filmmaker, played by Richard Gere.

title: Ubisoft, a case study in the 'return to office' debate
summary: After a strike that was  historic for the video game industry in October, Ubisoft's unions and management are negotiating a return to in-person work. The conflict illustrates the challenges involved in managing such a transition.

title: Anne Hidalgo, the Paris mayor praised abroad but unloved in France
summary: Hidalgo was recently lauded by several international publications for her fight against climate change. The international acclaim for her contrasts with her tenacious unpopularity at home.

title: Israeli says it struck 'military targets' in Yemen after intercepting a missile from the Houthi rebels
summary: This is the second time this week that Israel's military has intercepted a missile from Yemen. The first was Monday, a launch later claimed by Houthi rebels.

title: Syria: officials of Bashar al-Assad's ousted regime on trial in several European countries
summary: Judicial authorities in France, Germany, Switzerland, Belgium and the Netherlands have initiated proceedings against agents and senior officials of the former government, some of which have resulted in convictions.

title: 80 years of Le Monde: Your questions answered about how our newsroom works
summary: 'Who chooses the story?' 'Does artificial intelligence affect your job?' 'How long to write an article?': Le Monde's editorial team answered readers' questions as the newspaper celebrated its 80th anniversary on Wednesday, December 18.

title: Faced with nature's decline, the 'IPCC of biodiversity' calls for far-reaching systemic transformations
summary: As current biodiversity efforts are failing to halt its decline, an IPBES report outlines strategies for implementing 'transformative change.'

title: Mass rape trial: Follow the verdicts live
summary: The judges in the trial of 51 men accused of raping a heavily sedated Gisèle Pelicot are to deliver their verdicts on Thursday morning. The main accused, Gisèle Pelicot's ex-husband Dominique, faces 20 years in jail after admitting the charges.

title: Macron arrives in cyclone-hit Mayotte
summary: The French president arrived in Mayotte early on Thursday after the archipelago was hit by a devastating cyclone that officials fear has left hundreds, even thousands, dead.

title: Nicolas Sarkozy's historic prison sentence
summary: This is the first time such a heavy sentence has been handed down to a former French president. Sarkozy said he would refer the case to the European Court of Human Rights, putting him in the position of a former head of state who, having represented and defended France, is now seeking to have it condemned.

title: Gisèle Pelicot's ex-husband gets maximum 20 years sentence in mass rape trial
summary: Dominique Pelicot's 50 co-defendants were also convicted in a trial that has rocked France and beyond after Gisèle Pelicot waived her rights to anonymity and the world discovered how her husband drugged and raped her and enabled dozens of other men to rape her too.

title: Putin delivers annual news conference, says fall of Assad is not 'defeat' for Russia
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin said the fall of the Syrian regime led by Bashar al-Assad did not mean Russia had not completed its 'goals' in the country, during his annual address that he uses to reinforce his authority.

title: Interior minister puts spotlight on migration after devastating Mayotte cyclone
summary: The recently resigned interior minister Bruno Retailleau brought up immigration when discussing how to rebuild Mayotte after it was devastated by Cyclone Chido.

title: Gisèle Pelicot 'never regretted' opening French mass rape trial to public
summary: 'This trial has been a very difficult ordeal, and at this moment I am thinking first and foremost of my three children,' Gisèle Pelicot said as she left court after her husband and  50 other men were convicted in the landmark French rape trial.

title: Macron vows to 'rebuild' Mayotte after Cyclone Chido's devastation
summary: Visiting the French overseas department after the cyclone, the worst natural disaster in Mayotte in 90 years, struck the island, Macron heard shocked and angry reports from residents of France's poorest department.

title: Fewer visitors, better experiences: Taittinger pioneers new approach to champagne tourism
summary: Reopening after an 18-month renovation, the family-run champagne house in Reims has a surprising new approach to visitors – it wants to welcome fewer of them.

title: French football star Paul Pogba's brother sentenced to year in prison in extortion case
summary: Convicted for participating in the attempted extortion of €13 million from his brother, Mathias Pogba will be able to serve his one-year sentence with an electronic bracelet.

title: United States: Amazon workers go on strike before Christmas
summary: In a nationwide labor protest, around 10,000 Amazon workers affiliated with the Teamsters Union went on strike days before the busy holiday gift-giving season, citing management's refusal to negotiate for the timing.

title: Georgia at risk of Russian subjugation
summary: Vladimir Putin wants to recreate a Russian sphere of influence in the post-Soviet space. This is what is happening in Georgia, where the pro-European protest movement is being brutally repressed, embarrassing the European Union.

title: US CEO shooting suspect agrees to extradition to New York to face murder charge
summary: Luigi Mangione, 26, made two court appearances on Thursday, first waiving a hearing on forgery and firearms charges before agreeing to face a charge of second-degree murder as an act of terrorism in New York.
